search_results.lyrics:
Saw You in a Dream Lyrics[Verse 1]
I saw you in a dream
You had stayed the same
You were beckoning me
Said that I had changed
Tried to keep my eyes closed
I want you so bad
Then I awoke and it was so sad

[Pre-Chorus]
Haven't talked to you in months
And I thought that I might cry
But I'm not that kind of guy
[Verse 2]
I saw you in a dream
You came to me
You were the sweetest apparition, such a pretty vision
There was no reason, no explanation
The perfect hallucination

[Pre-Chorus]
All good things come to an end
But I thought that this might last
But you came and left so fast

[Chorus]
And when I'm awake I can't switch off
It isn't the same but it is enough
(It isn't the same but it is enough)

[Verse 3]
I saw you in a dream
Then it came to an end
I wonder if you'll come and visit me again
You're taking your time to reappear
I'm starting to believe that when I call your name

[Pre-Chorus]
You just don't hear me anymore
And I know that I shouldn't even try
It's a waste of time
You might also like[Chorus]
And when I'm awake I can't switch off
It isn't the same but it is enough
(It isn't the same but it is enough)

And when I'm awake I can't switch off
It isn't the same but it is enough
It isn't the same but it is enough16Embed

description.plain: “It’s my favorite song I’ve ever written. My voice doesn’t sound perfect, but it’s a really emotional song. It’s two live takes, and I think I was crying on one of them. It’s about my friend who passed away. I find it difficult to think of writing music as therapy because it’s not therapeutic for me to confront certain things. I have to play this song every night on tour and sometimes I don’t want to think about her being dead. Maybe it’s really nice that I get to think about her every day. It’s therapy but it’s also emotional torture.” – Amber Bain of The Japanese House

songs.title: Saw You In A Dream

annotations: I’m not that kind of guy

Though the narrator of the song is (presumably) female, “I’m not that kind of guy” is a common figure of speech and isn’t exclusively used to refer to men.

The line is likely written this way to complement the rhyming scheme of the previous line (“cry” and “guy”).

And when I’m awake I can’t switch off
 It isn’t the same but it is enough
 (It isn’t the same but it is enough)

(Partial Draft)

It isn’t the same to remember a person as it is to have them there. But maybe, having memories to keep those deceased alive in spirit, regardless of physical absence, is really be all anyone can ask for.

“Enough”, then, references how all that’s left is the memory kept alive by the still-living party. There is a sense of closure in this line, as the speaker comes to peace with the reality of the deceased party’s physical absence. In admitting that just having memories “isn’t the same” as having the person there, is a confrontation with their grief, but not one that stays defeated in said factuality. “But it is enough,” instead, brings a sort of melancholy reconciliation with how nothing is going to erase or replace that space of absence, but the speaker is more glad to have known them then they are sad that the person is gone.

The recognition of loss that holds the joy of having known over the pain of having lost.

Tried to keep my eyes closed
 I want you so bad
 Then I awoke and it was so sad

The speaker is aware that this interaction is a dream, but wants to hold on to it a little longer. Even knowing that it isn’t real, the sweetness of it isn’t diminished. Waking up was like loosing the person all over again, and even the knowledge that the younger was already dead didn’t make it easy.
Said that I had changed

At its simpelist, this line depicts a disparity between what the dream-person knew the speaker as and who they are now. When people are seperated, individual changes appear far more stark when they meet again.

But with regards to the artist’s intentions of the lines, the line recalls from the dream that the friend they saw, who had died when they were younger, noticed that the speaker had grown, as she was alive–and the deceased girl had not.

Thematically, this highlights the bittersweet reality of the experience: that regardless of the dream’s illusions, the real-world actuality permeated even the fantasy: that the younger girl is dead. Regardless of the scene in front of the speaker, the old friend is gone, and someplace untouchable for the speaker.
[Chorus]

The chorus is definitely upbeat – when I first wrote the chorus it actually sounded like Keane! I love Keane but I was like “this sounds like something Keane would write”. I wrote it on a guitar and was in the mindset of “I just really wanna write a song that doesn’t rely on fancy production”.

– Amber Bain, NME
I saw you in a dream

In a recent interview with British music journalism magazine NME, Bain explained that the song is about the apparition of a late childhood friend in a dream.

It’s about someone I was really close with when I was younger. But a couple of years ago they died. A bit after that I saw them in this dream and it was quite a weird situation, because I’d never experienced something like that before. So with this event I just sat down and was like, ‘right, I’m gonna write a song about this’. I think that’s why it’s one of my favourite songs that I’ve done just because it’s quite blatant. Even if you didn’t know the context for it, it would still make sense because it’s still a love song – a heart-break song.

description.plain:
“i saw you in a dream” is an acoustic version of The Japanese House’s own 2017 single “Saw You in a Dream.” This was confirmed during her 2018 UK tour.

The song focuses on the loss of a friend and their subsequent appearance in one of Amber’s dreams.

description.plain:
“Boyhood” is the lead single to Amber Bain’s second LP.

She tells BBC’s Radio 1, where the song debuted, that the decision behind choosing this track as her return to the scene was that “I was thinking a lot about being gay and gender-obsessed. And I was thinking a lot about how I don’t really feel like a woman or a girl, and so it’s strange ‘cause I grew up as a girl and I didn’t have a boyhood. I was sort of thinking about that and how different I might be if I’ve had some sort of boyhood or I’ve had some different things happened to me in my life. The song itself had a hundred different versions of it and I feel like I’ve had a hundred different versions of myself that could’ve existed and it’s about like accepting some of those…”

She tells BBC’s Radio 1, where the song debuted, that the decision behind choosing this track as her return to the scene was that “I was thinking a lot about being gay and gender-obsessed. And I was thinking a lot about how I don’t really feel like a woman or a girl, and so it’s strange ‘cause I grew up as a girl and I didn’t have a boyhood. I was sort of thinking about that and how different I might be if I’ve had some sort of boyhood or I’ve had some different things happened to me in my life. The song itself had a hundred different versions of it and I feel like I’ve had a hundred different versions of myself that could’ve existed and it’s about like accepting some of those…”

annotations: I went to meet to somebody new

This line harkens back to a lyric from “​went to meet her (intro),” off of The Japanese House’s album, [Good at Falling](:

Went to meet her in Ibiza
Me and Katie went to greet her

It seems fitting that “Boyhood,” The Japanese House’s first song in three years, has similarities to the opening track of her debut album.

description.plain:
“Maybe You’re the Reason” is the third single from the upcoming The Japanese House’s debut album, Good at Falling.

The single was officially released on the 13th of January, 2019 as the “Chillest Record” feature on Phil Taggart’s Radio 1’s Chillest Show.

The song focusses on depression and the feeling that nothing has any real meaning. The chorus turns this around, with the idea that “maybe loving someone is the reason you live.”

body.plain:
“Maybe You’re the Reason” is the third single from the upcoming The Japanese House’s debut album, Good at Falling.

The single was officially released on the 13th of January, 2019 as the “Chillest Record” feature on Phil Taggart’s Radio 1’s Chillest Show.

The song focusses on depression and the feeling that nothing has any real meaning. The chorus turns this around, with the idea that “maybe loving someone is the reason you live.”

annotations:
And I think I’m dying
 ’Cause this can’t be living
 Should I be searching for
 Some kind of meaning?

This verse uses a clever turn of phrase to explain Bain’s feelings of uselessness. “Should I be searching for some kind of meaning?” Could a be a reference to her affinity for studying/reading philosophy, which often has themes of questioning the purpose of living and human existence.

’Cause I’ve looked within and I’ve read
 But instead I keep focusing
 On just how thin I can get

In a footnote on the Bandcamp track listing, Bain writes:

“There’s a lyric, ‘I’ve looked within and I’ve read but instead I keep focusing on just how thin I can get.’ It’s me asking, ‘How can I be so clever and read philosophy but actually care about how thin I am?

Not that I think I have an eating disorder now, but I definitely did when I was younger. That was when I started to realize I’m writing some quite personal things, and I went with it."

https://thejapanesehouse.bandcamp.com/track/maybe-youre-the-reason

Or are we living for the feeling
 When we look back
 On what we did and reminisce?
Bain then turns the tables and rhetorically asks if we are all living for something more appealing to nostalgia (reminiscing) than creating something that will be fulfilling and last long.
Apathy’s a funny feeling

Although the chorus gives the song a more uplifting tone, it does seem like she’s trying to convince herself. She can’t get away from this terrible apathy, this inability to care about the life that she’s leading.
She plays with words a bit here- apathy is not a feeling, but the lack of feelings altogether.

Now I’m looking for something else
 I found myself: I’m someone else

In their search to find value in themself, the speaker realizes that who they have become is no longer someone they recognize. In the first line, the speaker, unable to find a purpose in their individual existence, instead looks outward. Their avoidance of defining themself by their own standards has allowed their identity to morph into something foreign, because it has been shaped by opinions and expectations outside themself.

As the artist has stated, this song deals with how there is no larger meaning to life — that perhaps a value of sorts can be found, instead, in how our love of others can give our life meaning and value.

“Finding themself” then, as stated here, is not that there is a disconnect between who they are as an individual, and who they want to be — but that it isn’t literally themself that they found at all. Instead, what they found was a personal reason to live in living for their love of another. “I’m someone else” is, then, just that: that it was in loving someone else that they found this purpose to life. This sentiment is supported in the third and sixth lines of the chorus: “Maybe you’re the reason.” The love of another is how the speaker has made peace with this existential angst of the absence of divine direction in life.

I keep looking for something
 Even though I know that it’s not there
 (Maybe you’re the reason)
 Every time I try to figure it out
 You’re the only thing I can think about
 (Maybe you’re the reason)

In the chorus, Amber chooses to break from the depressing tone of the verse, and focus on the feeling she had for her girlfriend at the time.

The idea that having a partner can feel like the reason you live is backed up by the longest-running study on happiness, which has found a strong association between happiness and close relationships like spouses, family, friends, and social circles.

Personal connection creates mental and emotional stimulation, which are automatic mood boosters, while isolation is a mood buster.

On the change of tone in the song, Amber has said:

In the chorus I thought, I can’t keep this up! I need to make it something nice. I thought about my girlfriend at the time, and how maybe loving someone is the reason you live? It’s the cheesiest chorus ever, but I think it needed it.

description.plain:
“Something Has to Change” is the first look into The Japanese House’s upcoming EP of the same name.
The song describes being stuck in a routine, not getting anywhere, and realizing you need to change.

The music video is the first to also feature Bain’s live band.

The song describes being stuck in a routine, not getting anywhere, and realizing you need to change.

annotations:
And it’s the same thing
 You’re repeating yourself
 And it’s the same girl who’s giving you hell
 And it’s the same face
 Your heart keeps breaking in the same place

This line is all about making romantic mistakes over and over and not learning your lesson from it. Amber is either addressing herself or someone else, but she’s clearly trying to make a point that this girl will keeping breaking hearts continuously. “Your heart keeps breaking in the same place” is interesting because not only is your heart breaking, but it’s breaking the same way, time after time.

And it’s the same thing
 You’re repeating yourself
 And it’s the same girl who’s giving you hell
 And it’s the same face
 Your heart keeps breaking in the same place

This line is all about making romantic mistakes over and over and not learning your lesson from it. Amber is either addressing herself or someone else, but she’s clearly trying to make a point that this girl will keeping breaking hearts continuously. “Your heart keeps breaking in the same place” is interesting because not only is your heart breaking, but it’s breaking the same way, time after time.

You caught the same train
 And you took it back
 To the same place
 You’re back where you started
 It’s the same thing
This song is about falling into a boring and/or mundane daily routine. Bain could be talking either to herself about her own daily life, or she could be addressing a friend or loved one.

description.plain: Amber is talking about herself here. She constantly puts on a happy face when around friends, so they would never guess that underneath she’s really a mess. There is a disconnect between Amber’s public persona and her personal relationship with people around her.

body.plain: Amber is talking about herself here. She constantly puts on a happy face when around friends, so they would never guess that underneath she’s really a mess. There is a disconnect between Amber’s public persona and her personal relationship with people around her.

songs.full_title: You Seemed So Happy - LA Session by The Japanese House
songs.title: You Seemed So Happy - LA Session
songs.title_with_featured: You Seemed So Happy - LA Session

annotations: All these things don’t matter to anybody like you

Amber is singing the words others might have spoken to her. From the outside, relationship issues usually don’t affect people in her category of fame. Amber originally tried to cover up her feelings, but instead found that her feelings were important and they do matter. Her feelings helped her to write her first full-length album.

Oh, you seemed so happy to everybody you knew
 These things don’t happen to anybody like you

Amber is talking about herself here, as other people would say to her that she appeared to be doing well. In reality, Amber was going through struggles with her relationship as well as some other personal problems. She tried to cover it up with fake happiness, and she partially succeeded because people do not expect celebrities or “successful” people to experience problems like this.
Sometimes I start believing in things that aren’t real
The “things that aren’t real” here are the fake emotions she puts on for the people around her, occasionally she can almost fool herself that she is actually happy and not just pretending.

body.plain:
This song was first teased by the 1975 band frontman via his Instagram story on January 31st, 2018 when they were producing the song.

You can find the video here:
https://www.instagram.com/p/BenmfDcFh7I/?utm_source=ig_share_sheet&igshid=1i7fjn4yg96cz

annotations: And now you’re taking up all of my time
In the age of social media and technology, it’s very easy to fall in to the trap of letting somebody take up your free time by going out of your way to look at their posts.

I wasted all my time
 Waiting for the stars
 To align

Often, especially when we have our heart set on somebody, it’s easy to do nothing and tell yourself things will simply fall into place.

An example of this could be watching somebody’s relationship from the outside, hoping that they leave their partner and come to you instead.

If things don’t go the way you’d hoped, this can leave you feeling like you’ve wasted your time.
Wherever you are: I’m with you from afar

This album was written while Amber was in a relationship with fellow musician Marika Hackman. Both of them toured often and thus the relationship was long distance at some parts. Thus though they weren’t always physically together, Amber was always “with” Marika and there for her from a different geographical location.

She makes me wonder why
 She makes me wonder what I’m doing
 Spending all these seconds away from her
 The time I’m losing
 Being far away, I’m lost in space
 Make it go away, all this space between us

This is a song about the bliss of being in love. The speaker is so complete that she stops seeing the point in doing anything else, as it doesn’t bring her nearly as much joy as being with her girlfriend.
In conflict with this, however, is the fact that at times she finds it hard to cherish these moments as they pass, thereby “losing” time by being “lost in space”.

search_results.title: Chewing Cotton Wool
search_results.lyrics:
Chewing Cotton Wool LyricsShe's the only one around
And she's turning off the lights
And she's inside every crack
She's the only thing in sight

She's the only one I see
And she's flying through the air
She's the dust upon the sill
She's everywhere
And she's breaking up the line
And she's sitting in the rain
She's the trailer for a film
She's the curtain at the end
She's the sound of your own voice
She's someone else's drink
She's like living in the countryside
She's the whirlpool in the sink
She's a memory I recall
And she's waiting in the hall
She's the monster in the fridge
She's chewing cotton woolYou might also like10Embed

description.plain:
The song ‘Chewing Cotton Wool’ chronicles the mourning process over a love lost; of a relationship that’s come to an end. Through metaphors and references, both the omnipresence and unattainability of the loved one is evoked.

In the song’s closing line – from which the track and the EP as a whole take their name – songwriter Amber Baines refers to this lover to be “chewing cotton wool”, a reference to this loved one’s (metaphorical or literal) death. In the act of conserving the body of a deceased person, an embalmer/mortician often places cotton gauze in the throat and mouth of the deceased to prevent leakage of bodily fluids and to make the mouth look more natural.

As with many of the songs on her album ‘Good At Falling’, this song – and the other tracks on the EP – closely relate to the relationship Amber Baines had with fellow British Singer-Songwriter Marika Hackman and the processing of the break-up.

body.plain:
The song ‘Chewing Cotton Wool’ chronicles the mourning process over a love lost; of a relationship that’s come to an end. Through metaphors and references, both the omnipresence and unattainability of the loved one is evoked.

In the song’s closing line – from which the track and the EP as a whole take their name – songwriter Amber Baines refers to this lover to be “chewing cotton wool”, a reference to this loved one’s (metaphorical or literal) death. In the act of conserving the body of a deceased person, an embalmer/mortician often places cotton gauze in the throat and mouth of the deceased to prevent leakage of bodily fluids and to make the mouth look more natural.

As with many of the songs on her album ‘Good At Falling’, this song – and the other tracks on the EP – closely relate to the relationship Amber Baines had with fellow British Singer-Songwriter Marika Hackman and the processing of the break-up.

annotations: She’s a memory I recall
This person is no longer physically accessible and can only be felt in a memory, because she has passed away.

She’s someone else’s drink
 She’s like living in the countryside

She’s someone else’s drink; She’s inaccessible, unattainable.
She’s like living in the countryside; Beautiful, lonely.

And she’s breaking up the line
 And she’s sitting in the rain
This is presumably less of a metaphor and more of a literal memory for Bain.

She’s the only one I see
 And she’s flying through the air
This whole song is about the loss of a loved one, and has a very haunting feeling to it. “flying through the air” is possibly referring to the subject of the song being a ghost.
She’s chewing cotton wool
Amber is revealing that She has passed. It’s a reference to the cotton gauze placed in the throat of a deceased by an embalmer for a funeral.
And she’s waiting in the hall

This line fits in with the haunted imagery of the rest of this verse. It sounds like Amber is dreading or fearing what is “waiting in the hall” like a child would fear walking back to the bathroom in the dark.
She’s everywhere
The girl the song is about is as prevalent to Amber as air particles, and everything reminds Amber of her, including literal dust upon the sill. Memories of her are everywhere.

She’s the trailer for a film
 She’s the curtain at the end

This line refers to how at the beginning of the relationship Amber could see a glimpse of their life together but as time went on she could only see how their love would end. ‘She’ is the beginning and the ending of the speaker’s thoughts.
She’s the dust upon the sill
the person is part of everyday life-the idea of this person is so ingrained that it’s almost annoying, like dust that needs to be cleaned off.
She’s the monster in the fridge

The monster in the fridge may illustrate a literal fear of getting something to eat, i.e. an eating disorder – inflicted by the pain she has suffered from the end of this relationship.

This line could also relate to the body in a mortuary refrigerator, being distorted and not how Amber would like to remember them – as if she looked like a monster. It’s also interesting how this is at the end of the song, after hearing how Amber describes how much this person means to her, and how upon death, she realises that all those things are no longer there, and that they only exist in memory.

search_results.title: Lilo
search_results.lyrics:

I needed someone to depend upon
I was alone, I was emotional
Searching for the right emoticon
To expand my mental lexicon

[Pre-Chorus 1]
Then Gemma told me that she met someone
It was the person I'd been counting on

A feeling I'd been waiting on

With your eyes closed, going where the tide goes

The feeling I'd been waiting for

With your eyes closed, going where the tide goes

Hold my breath another minute
I can keep my head, there's nothing in it

And it's an easy ride

Going where the tide goes
Floating like a lilo with you
Going where the tide goes
Floating like a–
Floating like a–
Floating like a–
Floating like a–

[Chorus]
You were floating like a lilo
With your eyes closed, going where the tide goes
Caught in flux, you drifted 'til you hit the sides
Hold my breath another minute
I can keep my head, there's nothing in it
I'm a patient wave (I'm a patient wave)
And it's an easy ride10Embed

description.plain:
“Lilo” is the first single released off of the highly anticipated debut album from The Japanese House. The single was released on the 27th of September, 2018 on Zane Lowe’s Hottest Record feature on Apple Music’s Beats 1 radio station.

The track focuses on a relationship Bain previously had, brought about after being introduced by close friend Gemma Janes. The imagery of a Lilo floating in a pool describes how the relationship felt, serene and easygoing.

Bain continues with the thematic use of water, as she had previously in “Pools to Bathe In”, “Cool Blue”, “Letter By The Water”, and “Swim Against the Tide”.

body.plain:
“Lilo” is the first single released off of the highly anticipated debut album from The Japanese House. The single was released on the 27th of September, 2018 on Zane Lowe’s Hottest Record feature on Apple Music’s Beats 1 radio station.

The track focuses on a relationship Bain previously had, brought about after being introduced by close friend Gemma Janes. The imagery of a Lilo floating in a pool describes how the relationship felt, serene and easygoing.

Bain continues with the thematic use of water, as she had previously in “Pools to Bathe In”, “Cool Blue”, “Letter By The Water”, and “Swim Against the Tide”.

songs.full_title: Lilo - LA Session by The Japanese House
songs.title: Lilo - LA Session

annotations:
With your eyes closed, going where the tide goes
 Caught in flux, you drifted ’til you hit the sides

Amber explained the meaning of these lines in an Instagram post. They are about her relationship with Marika Hackman and how, to Amber “her every movement – paired with her approach to life – seemed as serene as the image of lilo floating across a swimming pool”.

She began writing this song towards the end of their relationship and finished just after it had ended. It is a tribute to their time together and serves as a reminder to Amber that she “is good at falling in love and [she] can survive falling out of it”

The imagery of the lilo “[hitting] the sides” suggests that their relationship ended naturally and that there isn’t any resentment or bitterness from either of them towards the other – it was the right time for the relationship to end.

I needed someone to depend upon
 I was alone, I was emotional

As Amber explained in the song description, this song tells the story of a romance she fell into directly after a breakup in which she was heartbroken and lonely, before a friend (Gemma) suggested she meet a person she thought she might like.

I’m a patient wave
 And it’s an easy ride
This lyric continues the metaphor of floating in water, with Amber comparing herself to a peaceful wave.
I can keep my head, there’s nothing in it

This line is directly self-deprecating for Bain, a fairly common lyrical theme for her, as she likes to throw humorous and self deprecating lines into her songs. This is even proven by a line earlier in the song; “I saw myself an intellectual, I thought that I was capable” which lays out her inability to do or feel something that she had overestimated herself on.
I can keep my head, there’s nothing in it

This line is directly self-deprecating for Bain, a fairly common lyrical theme for her, as she likes to throw humorous and self deprecating lines into her songs. This is even proven by a line earlier in the song; “I saw myself an intellectual, I thought that I was capable” which lays out her inability to do or feel something that she had overestimated herself on.
I can keep my head, there’s nothing in it

This line is directly self-deprecating for Bain, a fairly common lyrical theme for her, as she likes to throw humorous and self deprecating lines into her songs. This is even proven by a line earlier in the song; “I saw myself an intellectual, I thought that I was capable” which lays out her inability to do or feel something that she had overestimated herself on.

Searching for the right emoticon
 To expand my mental lexicon

The mental lexicon is your brain’s analytical dictionary, which pins meanings to words/images/numbers/etc. This lyric could mean many things, but two big examples that stand out are:
The new age of technology allows us to analyze emoticons (emojis) with certain emotions or meanings, such as what one would think is a sleepy face, is actually perceived by society as a swooning face.
Or, alternatively, she’s texting someone (probably Gemma based on the next lyric) and she’s trying to find the right emoji to explain how she’s feeling without being too direct.

Then Gemma told me that she met somebody
 Nobody else could take me from myself

Amber Bain tells Apple Music, “My friend Gemma called me and said, ‘I’ve met someone that you’re gonna fall in love with.’ I was really heartbroken at the time, so I thought, ‘It’s not going to happen.’ Then I went to her gig, she was really funny onstage, and I thought, ‘Fuck.’ The chorus was written when we first met. The whole thing about her ‘floating like a lilo’ [pool float] is because it really did feel like she was just drifting around. She felt like a very singular object.”

I saw myself an intellectual
 I thought that I was capable
 Every move was just habitual
 And life was just a ritual

Going into a relationship there can be challenges we should be able to face with a level head and through logical thinking, but finding yourself in the middle of it is very different to looking back on the relationship. This person was caught up in the waves of the relationship so much that aspects of it became a habit and a ritual. It could be seen that this is the only place in the song where a tinge of regret is felt, as she thought she was capable of holding the relationship together; which contrasts to the overall acceptance the rest of the lyrics portray.

With your eyes closed, going where the tide goes
 Caught in flux, you drifted ’til you hit the sides

Amber explained the meaning of these lines in an Instagram post. They are about her relationship with Marika Hackman and how, to Amber “her every movement – paired with her approach to life – seemed as serene as the image of lilo floating across a swimming pool”.

She began writing this song towards the end of their relationship and finished just after it had ended. It is a tribute to their time together and serves as a reminder to Amber that she “is good at falling in love and [she] can survive falling out of it”

The imagery of the lilo “[hitting] the sides” suggests that their relationship ended naturally and that there isn’t any resentment or bitterness from either of them towards the other – it was the right time for the relationship to end.
